paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the Val50Met variant in the TTR gene, focusing on its penetrance and psychosocial impact on carriers and affected individuals.

patients.demographics: Not specified in detail, but includes both symptomatic patients and asymptomatic carriers.
patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTRv), primarily neuropathic symptoms.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Neuropathic symptoms, with some patients in stage I and others in stage II or higher.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Overall, 85 people completed the survey. Of them, 34 (40.0%) were symptomatic patients, 22 (64.7%) with stage I of the disease and 12 (35.3%) with stage II or higher.
The survey was also completed by 27 asymptomatic carriers (31.8%) and 24 relatives/caregivers.

functional_data.summary: The variant is associated with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, leading to amyloid fibril deposition.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in families, as indicated by the familial history of affected individuals.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the psychosocial burden associated with the Val50Met variant.
key_quotes: The disease had a greater impact on all of the areas assessed in patients than in asymptomatic carriers (p < 0.05).
Most participants (32 of 50; 64%) indicated that they had access to genetic counselling, largely motivated by family history.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper focused on the TTR gene and its associated variant.
